text: Go now to the flock, and fetch me from thence two good kids of the goats; and I will make them savoury meat for thy father, such as he loveth:
text_kjv: Go now to the flock, and fetch me from thence two good kids of the goats; and I will make them savoury meat for thy father, such as he loveth:
text_niv: Go out to the flock and bring me two choice young goats, so I can prepare some tasty food for your father, just the way he likes it.
text_esv: Go to the flock and bring me two good young goats, so that I may prepare from them delicious food for your father, such as he loves.
text_nlt: Go out to the flocks, and bring me two fine young goats. I’ll use them to prepare your father’s favorite dish.
text_msg: Go to the flock and get me two young goats. Pick the best; I'll prepare them into a hearty meal, the kind that your father loves.
text_nasb: 'Go now to the flock and bring me two choice young goats from there, that I may prepare them [as] a savory dish for your father, such as he loves.
context: Genesis 27:9 sits squarely within the narrative of Isaac's impending death and the pivotal moment of the patriarchal blessing. This blessing, in ancient Near Eastern culture, wasn't merely a wish for good fortune; it was a powerful, almost legally binding pronouncement transferring leadership, authority, and often material wealth to the designated heir. The patriarch held immense power, and his final blessing carried significant weight, shaping the future of the family and its descendants. Isaac, now old and visually impaired, intended to bestow this blessing upon Esau, his elder son, who he favored likely because Esau was a skilled hunter who provided Isaac with delicious game. This preference, however, flew in the face of God's earlier pronouncement (Genesis 25:23) that 'the older will serve the younger,' a revelation Rebekah clearly remembered and acted upon. The cultural context surrounding food is also important. Preparing a 'savoury meat' was an act of love and respect, often involving special recipes and techniques passed down through generations. It was a deliberate and thoughtful gesture intended to please the recipient. The 'two good kids of the goats' would have represented a significant portion of the family's livestock, highlighting the value placed on this final meal and the blessing it was supposed to secure. Goat was a common meat source, but the preparation would distinguish it and make it a special dish for a special occasion. Rebekah's instruction is not a casual request but a carefully planned act designed to deceive Isaac and manipulate the patriarchal system for what she believed was God's will.
meaning: Theologically, Genesis 27:9 is a cornerstone in understanding the complexities of divine sovereignty and human agency. While God had already declared Jacob's ascendancy, Rebekah's actions raise critical questions about the ethics of achieving God's will through deceit. The verse highlights the flawed nature of humanity, even within those who believe they are acting on God's behalf. Rebekah's manipulation stems from her belief that she knew God's will better than Isaac, who seemed determined to defy it. This introduces the dangerous concept of taking matters into one's own hands, presuming to act as God's agent without clear and unambiguous direction. The 'savoury meat' becomes a symbol of this deception. It's not just a meal; it's a tool used to manipulate Isaac's senses and cloud his judgment, leading him to unknowingly bestow the blessing on the 'wrong' son. The theological tension lies in reconciling God's sovereignty with Rebekah's sinful actions. Did God need Rebekah's deception to fulfill His purpose? Or would He have found another way to bring about His declared outcome? The narrative doesn't provide easy answers, forcing readers to grapple with the challenging interplay between human fallibility and divine providence. Furthermore, the contrast between Isaac's physical blindness and his spiritual blindness is significant. He is unable to see clearly, both literally and figuratively, clinging to his personal preferences instead of discerning God's will. This reinforces the idea that true sight comes not from physical perception but from spiritual discernment.
application: In modern life, Genesis 27:9 serves as a potent reminder of the dangers of manipulation and the importance of integrity, even when we believe we are pursuing a 'good' outcome. We often face situations where we are tempted to bend the truth, exaggerate, or use others to achieve our goals, especially when we are convinced that those goals are aligned with a higher purpose. This verse challenges us to critically examine our motives and methods. Are we truly seeking God's will, or are we simply justifying our own desires under the guise of righteousness? Rebekah's example highlights the slippery slope of justifying unethical behavior. We must be wary of rationalizing our actions by claiming they are necessary to fulfill God's plan. True faith requires us to trust that God can achieve His purposes without our resorting to deceit or manipulation. Furthermore, the verse underscores the importance of honesty and transparency in our relationships. Deception, even when well-intentioned, erodes trust and damages connections. Building strong and lasting relationships requires us to be truthful and authentic in our interactions. We should strive to communicate openly and honestly, even when it's difficult. Isaac's favoritism towards Esau, despite knowing God's pronouncement, serves as a warning against allowing personal preferences to cloud our judgment. We must be willing to set aside our own biases and prejudices in order to discern God's will and act accordingly. This verse also challenges us to be cautious about those who claim to know God's will with absolute certainty. Humility and a willingness to listen to others are essential for navigating complex ethical dilemmas. The pursuit of righteousness requires us to engage in thoughtful reflection, prayerful discernment, and honest self-examination.
prayer: Heavenly Father, forgive us for the times we have sought to manipulate situations or people to achieve our own ends, even when we thought we were acting in your name. Help us to recognize the temptation to bend the truth or use others to fulfill our desires. Grant us the wisdom to discern your will and the courage to follow it, even when it is difficult. Purify our motives and cleanse our hearts of any deceit or hidden agendas. Give us the strength to be honest and transparent in our relationships, building trust and fostering genuine connection. Help us to see others as you see them, with compassion and understanding. May our actions always be guided by integrity and a sincere desire to honor you in all that we do. Lord, help us to trust that you are able to accomplish your purposes without our resorting to manipulation or deceit. Strengthen our faith and deepen our reliance on your guidance. In Jesus' name, we pray. Amen.

faqs.answer: Rebekah likely favored Jacob because God revealed to her before their birth that the older brother (Esau) would serve the younger (Jacob). This divine pronouncement instilled in her a desire to ensure God's plan came to fruition, although her methods were questionable. She remembered God's word and took action to orchestrate the blessing towards Jacob.
faqs.question: Q1: Why did Rebekah favor Jacob over Esau?

faqs.answer: No. While Rebekah believed she was acting in accordance with God's will, her deceitful methods were not justified. The Bible consistently condemns lying and manipulation, regardless of the perceived end. God does not need our sin to achieve His purposes. Her actions demonstrate a lack of trust in God's ability to fulfill His promises.
faqs.question: Q2: Was Rebekah's deception justified because she was fulfilling God's will?

faqs.answer: The 'savoury meat' symbolizes deception and manipulation. It represents the means by which Rebekah intended to deceive Isaac and influence his decision. It highlights the deliberate and calculated nature of her plan to secure the blessing for Jacob and points to the lengths she was willing to go to.
faqs.question: Q3: What does 'savoury meat' symbolize in this passage?

faqs.answer: Isaac's physical blindness mirrors his spiritual blindness. He is unable to see clearly, both literally and figuratively, clinging to his personal preferences (favoring Esau) instead of discerning God's will. This emphasizes the importance of spiritual discernment over physical perception in making important life decisions.
faqs.question: Q4: How does Isaac's blindness contribute to the story's meaning?

faqs.answer: This story teaches us the importance of trusting God's timing and methods. Rebekah's impatience and lack of trust led her to take matters into her own hands, resulting in deception and family conflict. True faith requires us to believe that God is capable of fulfilling His promises without our manipulation or sinful actions.
faqs.question: Q5: What can we learn from this story about the importance of trusting God?
